keyTakeAways: Novo Nordisk is undergoing a significant boardroom overhaul with seven members, including the chairman, stepping down due to disagreements with its majority shareholder.
The Novo Nordisk Foundation, which owns 28.1% of shares and holds three-quarters of voting rights, has substantial influence over company governance and leadership decisions.
The board and the foundation disagreed on the scale of restructuring, with the foundation pushing for a more extensive reconfiguration than the board proposed.
Ozempic and Wegovy have driven substantial growth and market value, but increased competition from rivals like Eli Lilly is eroding profits and share prices.
The company has already announced cost-saving measures, reduced profit growth forecasts, and laid off 9,000 employees as part of a broader cost-cutting strategy.
Lars Rebien Sorensen, former CEO of Novo Nordisk and current head of the Novo Nordisk Foundation, is being proposed to take over as chairman, signaling continuity with past leadership.
The board claims the company has been slow in adapting to market changes, such as the off-label use of drugs for weight loss and entry of competitors.
The boardroom shake-up reflects broader tensions between operational governance and shareholder control in the pharmaceutical industry.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Novo Nordisk, the maker of Ozempic and Wegovy, is experiencing a major boardroom shake-up with seven members—including chairman Helge Lund and vice chairman Henrik Poulsen—departing due to a conflict with its majority shareholder, the Novo Nordisk Foundation. The foundation, which holds a three-quarter voting interest, pushed for a more extensive reconfiguration than the board proposed, leading to the removal of former CEO Lars Fruergaard Jorgensen. The company's market value, once at its peak in 2024 as Europe's most-valuable firm, has declined due to competition from rivals like Eli Lilly and growing concerns over profit growth. The boardroom changes come amid broader strategic shifts, including a 9,000-employee layoff, cost-cutting measures, and reduced profit forecasts, as the company adapts to shifting market dynamics and off-label demand for weight-loss drugs.
title: Ozempic maker Novo Nordisk's board shaken up as directors quit
